* **Affected Regions:** US East (Virginia), EU West (Amsterdam), Southeast Asia (Singapore), US West (California)
* **Affected Service:** Railway Metal deployment infrastructure

* **Current Status:** Monitoring - Fix deployed and under observation

### GLM-OCR: Advanced Multimodal Document Understanding Model

* **State-of-the-art OCR model** with 0.9B parameters, achieving 94.62 score on OmniDocBench V1.5 (#1 ranking)
* **Built on GLM-V architecture** combining CogViT visual encoder, cross-modal connector, and GLM-0.5B decoder with Multi-Token Prediction (MTP) loss
* **Three deployment options**: Zhipu MaaS cloud API (no GPU needed), self-hosted vLLM/SGLang, or Ollama/MLX for Apple Silicon
* **Comprehensive SDK** with CLI, Python API, and Flask service supporting single images, directories, and multi-page documents
* **Flexible output formats**: JSON structured data and Markdown, with optional PP-DocLayout-V3 layout detection
* **Optimized for production**: Handles complex tables, code blocks, seals, and challenging layouts with low latency and high concurrency support
* **Easy integration**: One-line installation via UV, simple configuration via YAML, and modular architecture for custom pipelines
* **Open source**: Available on Hugging Face and ModelScope under MIT License (model) and Apache 2.0 (code)

### Why Vampires Live Forever

* Based on the title, this article likely explores the metaphorical concept of "vampires" in technology, business, or systems - entities that persist indefinitely by consuming resources from their environment
* It probably discusses why certain legacy systems, outdated technologies, or organizational patterns refuse to die despite being obsolete, drawing parallels to vampire mythology
* The piece might examine the mechanisms that allow these "vampires" to survive: dependency lock-in, technical debt, institutional inertia, or network effects that keep them alive
* Could be interesting to readers because it addresses a common frustration in tech - dealing with systems that should have been retired long ago but continue to drain resources and attention

## ğŸ”¥ GitHub Trending / GitHub çƒ­é—¨é¡¹ç›®

### LangExtract - LLM-Powered Structured Information Extraction with Source Grounding

* **What it does**: Extracts structured information from unstructured text using LLMs, mapping every extraction back to its exact source location for verification and visualization
* **Key features**: Precise source grounding with visual highlighting, reliable structured outputs via few-shot learning, optimized for long documents with chunking and parallel processing, interactive HTML visualization, supports cloud (Gemini, OpenAI) and local models (Ollama), domain-agnostic with no fine-tuning required
* **Why it's notable**: Solves the "needle-in-a-haystack" problem for large document extraction while maintaining traceabilityâ€”particularly valuable for clinical notes, legal documents, and research papers where accuracy and source verification are critical. The 3,177 stars today reflect strong interest in production-ready LLM extraction tools that balance flexibility with reliability.

---

### GitHub Agentic Workflows - AI-Powered Automation for GitHub Actions

* **What it does**: Enables developers to write AI agent workflows in natural language markdown that execute within GitHub Actions, automating repository tasks through conversational instructions rather than traditional code

* **Key features**:
  * Natural language workflow definitions in markdown format
  * Built-in security guardrails with read-only defaults and sandboxed execution
  * Multiple protection layers: input sanitization, network isolation, SHA-pinned dependencies, and tool allow-listing
  * Human approval gates for critical operations
  * Integration with companion projects (Agent Workflow Firewall for network control, MCP Gateway for protocol routing)
  * Team-gated access controls

* **Why it's notable**: This represents GitHub's official foray into agentic AI automation, combining the power of AI agents with GitHub Actions' infrastructure while prioritizing security through comprehensive guardrails. With 389 stars today, it's gaining rapid traction as developers explore AI-driven workflow automation. The project bridges the gap between natural language instructions and automated repository operations, though it requires careful human supervision and comes with explicit security warnings.

---

### Microsoft PowerToys - Windows Productivity Utilities Suite

* What it does: A comprehensive collection of 25+ utilities that enhance Windows functionality, including window management (FancyZones), advanced clipboard operations (Advanced Paste), quick file operations (PowerRename, Image Resizer), system customization tools (Keyboard Manager, Color Picker), and productivity boosters (PowerToys Run launcher, Text Extractor OCR, Workspaces)

* Key features: Window snapping and layouts, bulk file renaming, image resizing, keyboard remapping, color picking, always-on-top windows, mouse utilities, registry editing, screen measurement, quick accent input, file preview enhancements, hosts file editing, and cross-monitor mouse control

* Why it's notable: Official Microsoft open-source project with 48 stars today, actively maintained with frequent updates (v0.97.2 released Feb 2025), supports both x64 and ARM64 architectures, available through multiple installation methods (GitHub, Microsoft Store, WinGet), and provides power-user features that significantly boost Windows productivity without requiring third-party tools

## ğŸš€ Fast-Moving Repos / å¿«é€Ÿå´›èµ·é¡¹ç›®

### CodePilot - Native Desktop GUI for Claude Code

* A cross-platform desktop application that wraps Claude Code in a polished visual interface, replacing terminal-based interactions with a full-featured GUI for conversational AI coding
* Real-time streaming chat with Claude models (Opus/Sonnet/Haiku), persistent SQLite session management, project-aware file tree with live previews, resizable panels, file/image attachments, granular permission controls, MCP server integration, custom slash commands and skills, token usage tracking, and dark/light themes
* Notable for bringing Claude's powerful coding agent to non-technical users and developers who prefer visual tools, with 1,689 stars reflecting strong demand for accessible AI coding interfaces. Built with modern stack (Electron + Next.js 16 + Radix UI) and ships pre-built binaries for macOS, Windows, and Linux with automated CI/CD

### CodePilot - Claude Code åŸç”Ÿæ¡Œé¢å›¾å½¢ç•Œé¢

* è·¨å¹³å°æ¡Œé¢åº”ç”¨ï¼Œä¸º Claude Code æä¾›ç²¾ç¾çš„å¯è§†åŒ–ç•Œé¢ï¼Œç”¨å®Œæ•´çš„ GUI åŠŸèƒ½æ›¿ä»£åŸºäºç»ˆç«¯çš„äº¤äº’ï¼Œå®ç°å¯¹è¯å¼ AI ç¼–ç¨‹
* ä¸ Claude æ¨¡å‹ï¼ˆOpus/Sonnet/Haikuï¼‰å®æ—¶æµå¼å¯¹è¯ã€åŸºäº SQLite çš„æŒä¹…åŒ–ä¼šè¯ç®¡ç†ã€é¡¹ç›®æ„ŸçŸ¥çš„æ–‡ä»¶æ ‘ä¸å®æ—¶é¢„è§ˆã€å¯è°ƒæ•´å¤§å°çš„é¢æ¿ã€æ–‡ä»¶/å›¾ç‰‡é™„ä»¶ã€ç»†ç²’åº¦æƒé™æ§åˆ¶ã€MCP æœåŠ¡å™¨é›†æˆã€è‡ªå®šä¹‰æ–œæ å‘½ä»¤å’ŒæŠ€èƒ½ã€Token ä½¿ç”¨è¿½è¸ªã€æ·±è‰²/æµ…è‰²ä¸»é¢˜

### The Vibe Companion - Open-Source Web UI for Claude Code

* What it does: Brings Claude Code out of the terminal and into your browser. Reverse-engineered the CLI's hidden WebSocket protocol to create a visual interface for running AI coding sessions. Works with your existing Claude Code subscriptionâ€”no API key needed.

* Key features: Multiple concurrent sessions, real-time streaming responses, visual tool call approval (bash commands, file edits, etc.), hierarchical subagent tracking, four permission modes, session persistence with auto-recovery, and environment profile management. Built with Bun, Hono, React 19, and Tailwind v4.

* Why it's notable: Solves major pain points of CLI-only AI coding toolsâ€”no visual feedback, single session limitation, lost context on crashes. The team documented the entire undocumented WebSocket protocol, making it possible to build alternative interfaces. One-command setup (`bunx the-vibe-companion`) and it just works on localhost:3456.

---

### The Vibe Companion - Claude Code å¼€æºç½‘é¡µç•Œé¢

* åŠŸèƒ½ä»‹ç»: å°† Claude Code ä»ç»ˆç«¯å¸¦åˆ°æµè§ˆå™¨ä¸­ã€‚é€šè¿‡é€†å‘å·¥ç¨‹ CLI éšè—çš„ WebSocket åè®®,åˆ›å»ºäº†å¯è§†åŒ–çš„ AI ç¼–ç ä¼šè¯ç•Œé¢ã€‚ä½¿ç”¨ç°æœ‰çš„ Claude Code è®¢é˜…å³å¯è¿è¡Œ,æ— éœ€ API å¯†é’¥ã€‚

* ä¸»è¦ç‰¹ç‚¹: æ”¯æŒå¤šä¸ªå¹¶å‘ä¼šè¯ã€å®æ—¶æµå¼å“åº”ã€å¯è§†åŒ–å·¥å…·è°ƒç”¨å®¡æ‰¹(bash å‘½ä»¤ã€æ–‡ä»¶ç¼–è¾‘ç­‰)ã€åˆ†å±‚å­ä»£ç†è¿½è¸ªã€å››ç§æƒé™æ¨¡å¼ã€ä¼šè¯æŒä¹…åŒ–ä¸è‡ªåŠ¨æ¢å¤ã€ç¯å¢ƒé…ç½®æ–‡ä»¶ç®¡ç†ã€‚æŠ€æœ¯æ ˆé‡‡ç”¨ Bunã€Honoã€React 19 å’Œ Tailwind v4ã€‚

### ğŸ¬ Have you ever wondered where Python got its name?

* Key topics discussed: The etymology and naming inspiration for Python, likely covering Guido van Rossum's choice to name it after Monty Python's Flying Circus rather than the snake
* Why it's worth watching: A fun, quick dive into programming history that reveals the playful origins of one of the world's most popular programming languages - perfect for Python enthusiasts and anyone curious about tech trivia
